param.name: rnk_file
param.label: Ranked Genes list
param.help: A tabular file with gene symbols in the first column, and a ranked statistic (e.g. t-statistic or log fold-change) in the second column

param.name: file_has_header
param.help: If this option is set to TRUE, the tool will assume that the ranked gene-list has a column heading and the gene names commence on the second line
param.label: Does the input ranked gene list have a header line?

param.name: gmt_file
param.label: Select the name of the MSIGDB collection you want to test enrichment for
param.help: This drop-down allows you to select gene sets from the Molecular Signatures Database (MSigDB) on the GSEA website. This provides access to only the most recent versions of MSigDB.
param.option: c6: all oncogenic signatures gene set
c7: all immunologic signatures gene sets

param.name: min_size
param.help: Minimal size of a gene set to test. All pathways below the threshold are excluded.
param.label: Minimum Size of Gene Set?

param.name: max_size
param.help: Maximal size of a gene set to test. All pathways above the threshold are excluded.
param.label: Maximal Size of Gene Set?

param.name: n_perm
param.help: Specifies the number of permutations to perform in assessing the statistical significance of the enrichment score. It is best to start with a small number, such as 10, in order to check that your analysis will complete successfully (e.g., ensuring you have gene sets that satisfy the minimum and maximum size requirements and that the collapsing genes to symbols works correctly). After the analysis completes successfully, run it again with a full set of permutations. The recommended number of permutations is 1000. Default: 1000
param.label: Number of Permutations

param.name: top_n
param.help: The N gene sets with the most-significant p-values will be plotted. The N most up-regulated and N most down-regulated sets will be shown. So the actual number of plots shown could be twice this parameter
param.label: Top N genes to plot

data.name: individual_plot
data.label: multi-page pdf with plots for top N gene sets

tool.help:
** Disclaimer ** This section is taken from the help page for the GSEAPreanked tool in GenePattern: http://software.broadinstitute.org/cancer/software/genepattern/modules/docs/GSEAPreranked/1
** Introduction **
This tool runs Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) against a user-supplied, ranked list of genes. It determines whether a priori defined sets of genes show statistically significant enrichment at either end of the ranking. A statistically significant enrichment indicates that the biological activity (e.g., biomolecular pathway) characterized by the gene set is correlated with the user-supplied ranking.
** Details **
Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) is a powerful analytical method for interpreting gene expression data. It evaluates cumulative changes in the expression of groups of multiple genes defined based on prior biological knowledge.
The GSEAPreranked module can be used to conduct gene set enrichment analysis on data that do not conform to the typical GSEA scenario. For example, it can be used when the ranking metric choices provided by the GSEA module are not appropriate for the data, or when a ranked list of genomic features deviates from traditional microarray expression data (e.g., GWAS results, ChIP-Seq, RNA-Seq, etc.).
The user provides GSEAPreranked with a pre-ranked gene list. Paired with each gene in the list is the numeric ranking statistic, which GSEAPreranked uses to rank order genes in descending order. GSEAPreranked calculates an enrichment score for each gene set. A gene set’s enrichment score reflects how often members of that gene set occur at the top or bottom of the ranked data set (for example, in expression data, in either the most highly expressed genes or the most underexpressed genes).
** References **
